item.title: Pain Science in Practice (Part 8): Nociceptive, Neuropathic, and Nociplastic Pain
item.description: Feld: Clinical Medicine Kategorie: Orthopedics Score: 24 Autoren: Morten Hoegh, Paul Hodges Journal: Journal of Orthopaedic & Sports Physical Therapy Veröffentlicht: 2025-09-01 Abstract: Synopsis: Identifying pain descriptors provides a way to tailor pain management based on presumed underlying mechanisms. The aim is to use mechanistic pain descriptors (nociceptive, neuropathic, and nociplastic pain) to guide clinical practice into an era of personalized medicine for people with pain. Clinicians should understand the concept of descriptors to improve their understanding of a mechanism-based management of chronic pain. Nonetheless, all treatment of individuals suffering from chronic pain should be holistic (ie, person-centered). Nociplastic pain already serves as an evidence-based explanation that can help make sense of pain without any known pathology, but is not ready to be considered as a target for treatment in itself, based on the current level of evidence. To summarize, treatment outcomes may improve when treatments are matched to patients according to mechanistic descriptors. Current research initiatives are working on bring this closer to the clinic. J Orthop Sports Phys Ther 2025;55(9):1-6. Epub 29 July 2025. doi:10.2519/jospt.2025.13335 DOI: 10.2519/jospt.2025.13335 ISSN: 0190-6011 Tag der Erhebung (OOIR): 2025-09-01
